GClasses::GPolynomial

GClasses::GPolynomial Class Reference

This regresses a multi-dimensional polynomial to fit the data. More...

#include <GPolynomial.h>

 Returns the number of control points (per dimension).
double coefficient (int *pCoords)
 Returns the coefficient at the specified coordinates. pCoords should be an array of size m_nDimensions, and each value should be from 0 to m_nControlPoints - 1.

 Returns the full array of coefficients.

void copy (GPolynomial *pOther)
 Copies pOther into this polynomial. Both polynomials must have the same dimensionality, and this polynomial must have >=.

 Regress the polynomial using all the samples in a collection.

 See the comment for GSupervisedLearner::predict.

void setCoefficients (const double *pVector)
 Sets all the coefficients. pVector must be of size GetCoefficientCount().
void toBezierCoefficients ()
 Converts to a multi-dimensional Bezier curve.
void fromBezierCoefficients ()
 Converts from a multi-dimensional Bezier curve.
void differentiate ()
 Differentiates the polynomial with respect to every dimension.
void integrate ()
 Integrates the polynomial in every dimension. This assumes the constant of integration is always zero. It also assumes that all of the highest-order coefficients are zero. If that isn't true, this polynomial won't be big enough to hold the answer, and the highest-order coefficients will be dropped. The best way to ensure that doesn't happen is to copy into a bigger (one more control point) polynomial before integrating.

Static Public Member Functions

static void test ()
 Performs unit tests for this class. Throws an exception if there is a failure.

Protected Member Functions

int calcIndex (int *pDegrees)
 This converts from control-point-lattice coordinates to an array index. The array is stored with lattice position (0, 0, 0, ...) (the constant coefficient) in array position 0, and lattice position (1, 0, 0, ...) in position 1, etc.

int m_featureDims

double * m_pCoefficients

Detailed Description

This regresses a multi-dimensional polynomial to fit the data.

Member Function Documentation

int GClasses::GPolynomial::calcIndex ( int *  pDegrees  )  [protected]

This converts from control-point-lattice coordinates to an array index. The array is stored with lattice position (0, 0, 0, ...) (the constant coefficient) in array position 0, and lattice position (1, 0, 0, ...) in position 1, etc.

void GClasses::GPolynomial::integrate (  ) 

Integrates the polynomial in every dimension. This assumes the constant of integration is always zero. It also assumes that all of the highest-order coefficients are zero. If that isn't true, this polynomial won't be big enough to hold the answer, and the highest-order coefficients will be dropped. The best way to ensure that doesn't happen is to copy into a bigger (one more control point) polynomial before integrating.
